Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: They scan items during a slow afternoon with a few customers in line.
Story:
I stood behind the register, the soft beep of the scanner breaking the quiet of a slow afternoon. My phone buzzed in my pocket—our family group chat lighting up with messages about this weekend’s plans. My stepdad wanted everyone’s input, and my mom had already hinted that I should be more involved, especially since I’d missed the last movie night. I glanced at the screen, seeing my stepsister’s name pop up, asking if I’d join them for the hike. 

A customer approached, placing groceries on the belt. I forced a smile, scanning each item, but my mind was split. I knew I was expected to be present, to show I cared about this new family, but I also couldn’t afford to mess up at work. My manager had warned me last week about distractions at the register. The line behind the customer grew, and my phone buzzed again—this time, my mom asking for a quick answer. My hands hesitated over the register, heart pounding, torn between replying to my family and focusing on the transaction in front of me.
